Award.AwardTitle: Inquiry-based Learning Strategies and Student Engagement

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is evaluating the effect of data-logging and GIS technology on student learning and engagement when integrated into introductory geoscience courses at Valencia Community College, an urban, minority-serving institution. The affordable data-logging technology allows students to collect and process physical data such as air and water quality information. With the addition of inexpensive GIS technology, students are assessing their collected data within a spatial context, adding an additional dimension to their understanding and interpretation of the physical world. The project is designed around two courses for non-majors: a laboratory physical geology course and a field-based course. In both courses, students are using data-logging and GIS technology to collect, process, and interpret data, as well as to present their conclusions to their instructor and peers. In the physical geology lab course, student learning is being enhanced by: 1) guided-inquiry using prepared activities, 2) open-ended inquiry activities using existing raw data sets, 3) open-ended inquiry where students collect, process, and interpret their own data, and 4) a combination of guided- and open-ended inquiry activities using data collected by the students and using public domain data sets (NOAA, USGS, etc.). In the summer field research course, students are carrying out authentic inquiries following a Research Experience for Undergraduates model. The summer research experience utilizes and builds on the skills developed by the students in the prerequisite physical geology laboratory course. Student learning and engagement are being evaluated using both qualitative and quantitative methods, and project results are being disseminated through a variety of active approaches.

This project is providing undergraduate research experiences for a diverse, community college student population lacking access to industry or university research facilities. Students are being introduced to data-logging technology and inquiry activities that maximize the availability and use of limited geologic resources. Because these activities are focusing on data actually available for collection, students are developing a better understanding of local geologic resources. The project is informing numerous geoscience programs in regions with limited geologic resources and/or access to expensive research facilities by incorporating and evaluating affordable data-logging technology that can be used anywhere. Consequently, the project is developing a realistic and adoptable model for engaging community college students in authentic geoscience research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was funded by NSF TUES I grant. This grant supported purchase of digital sensors and classroom equipment, student participation in field courses, and faculty participation in workshops introducing inquiry-based learning and disseminating techniques and materials developed during this project.

Many geoscience majors report becoming interested in geoscience through field experiences typically offered by 4-year institutions in freshman and sophomore years. About 50% of college students complete their first 2 years at 2-year colleges, often at institutions that do not have the resources or nearby locations to provide these field experiences. As a result, it is important for 2-year colleges to understand which experiences are most effective in engaging students in the geosciences. In order to address this issue, this project measured student interest in a variety of inquiry-based activities.

Students in physical geology classes used digital sensors and Ipads (using the Sparkvue app that allowed them to create kml files to upload into Google Earth) to map investigate correlation of soil types with vegetation, to map weathering features and types, to evaluate spatial and temporal variation in CO2, infrared radiation, barometric pressure, wind speed and direction, and absolute and relative humidity. They downloaded kml files and used Google Earth tools to create online portfolios evaluating a tectonic plate of their choice. Students also used stream tables and groundwater models in developing and implementing inquiry investigations.

Students who successfully completed physical geology were offered the opportunity to participate in a summer field course, including a 10-day trip to the Mount Rogers area of southwestern Virginia. Each student developed their own research project and completed posters of their results. Over 3 summers, 13 students participated in the summer class, 5 presented their posters on campus, 1 presented a poster at the 2016 Florida Undergraduate Research Conference, and another is planning to present at the upcoming 2017 conference.

Student personal interest in geoscience was measured using pre- and post-surveys in physical geology classes over 3 semesters. Situational interest was measured using surveying based on the experience sampling method (ESM). Students completed a 17-question real-time survey as they were working on various activities (11 -14 per semester). Students also participated in end-of-semester focus groups, discussing their interest in the different activities. Student sustained interest was measured by subsequent enrollment in a summer geology field course and by ongoing participation in a closed-group Facebook page.

A presentation was made at the 2014 Geological Society of America meeting proposing a model for integrating undergraduate research experiences into a 2-year college summer field course. Results of the interest surveys and assessments will be prepared for publication in an education journal and shared in presentations and posters at Geological Society of America meetings. In addition, the real-time ESM survey will be made available for use by other researcher interested in using this survey to measure situational interest, either through publication or through the SERC website. Preliminary results of this study suggest that students are most engaged when they are provided greater autonomy in choosing the questions to investigate and when they are learning outdoors.  

As part of the dissemination process for the project, 2 workshops on inquiry-based learning were provided to faculty of Valencia College in July, 2016. The workshops introduced evidence-based information and models of inquiry-based learning and provided participants with opportunities to use equipment, databases, and programs that they could use with their students in a variety of disciplines. The Valencia College Faculty Development program is looking at including inquiry-based learning workshops as part of their faculty development curriculum.
